cognitive_walkthrough.goal: Find and validate Daily Wage Calculator feature

page_analysis.title: Bayzat
headings: Good to see you Bayzlander bayzatcom

claim_ui_checks.claim: Current system cannot automatically calculate salary based on actual working days, requiring manual interventions and separate tracking.

checks.name: semantic_payroll_automation_gap
checks.claim_text: Current system cannot automatically calculate salary based on actual working days, requiring manual interventions and separate tracking.

claim_ui_checks.claim: The daily wage calculator in payroll settings intentionally overrides the leave policy formula for unpaid leave. The leave policy formula appears greyed out, indicating it is not active. This creates user confusion about which formula is actually being applied for daily wage calculations.

checks.name: semantic_daily_wage_formula_override
checks.claim_text: The daily wage calculator in payroll settings intentionally overrides the leave policy formula for unpaid leave. The leave policy formula appears greyed out, indicating it is not active. This creates user confusion about which formula is actually being applied for daily wage calculations.

claim_ui_checks.claim: System failed to recalculate pending unpaid leave deductions when new salary configurations were created after leave request submission. Deductions were calculated based on previous salary configuration instead of current one, resulting in incorrect payroll deduction amount.

checks.name: semantic_unpaid_leave_deduction_calculation
checks.claim_text: System failed to recalculate pending unpaid leave deductions when new salary configurations were created after leave request submission. Deductions were calculated based on previous salary configuration instead of current one, resulting in incorrect payroll deduction amount.

claim_ui_checks.claim: The End of Service (EOS) gratuity calculator incorrectly calculates service days by using 365 days instead of 366 days for leap years, specifically for 2024. This results in an inaccurate total service period and lower gratuity amount.

checks.name: semantic_leap_year_calculation_error
checks.claim_text: The End of Service (EOS) gratuity calculator incorrectly calculates service days by using 365 days instead of 366 days for leap years, specifically for 2024. This results in an inaccurate total service period and lower gratuity amount.

claim_ui_checks.claim: End of Service (EOS) calculation is producing incorrect pro-rated amounts due to a rounding or decimal precision error. The daily wage formula (basic + allowances / 30) is configured correctly, but when calculating pro-rated EOS amounts, the system consistently shows amounts that are less than expected by 0.1 or 0.2 decimals.

checks.name: semantic_eos_calculation_decimal_precision
checks.claim_text: End of Service (EOS) calculation is producing incorrect pro-rated amounts due to a rounding or decimal precision error. The daily wage formula (basic + allowances / 30) is configured correctly, but when calculating pro-rated EOS amounts, the system consistently shows amounts that are less than expected by 0.1 or 0.2 decimals.

claim_ui_checks.claim: Gratuity calculation involves tiered rates (21 days per year for first 5 years, 30 days per year after) and prorated calculations for partial years

checks.name: semantic_gratuity_calculation_complexity
checks.claim_text: Gratuity calculation involves tiered rates (21 days per year for first 5 years, 30 days per year after) and prorated calculations for partial years

claim_ui_checks.claim: The system's gratuity calculation may not consistently handle leap year days (February 29th), causing slight discrepancies in total service days calculation. The specific issue involves whether the extra day in a leap year (92 vs 93 days in 2024) impacts the total service duration calculation.

checks.name: semantic_leap_year_day_calculation
checks.claim_text: The system's gratuity calculation may not consistently handle leap year days (February 29th), causing slight discrepancies in total service days calculation. The specific issue involves whether the extra day in a leap year (92 vs 93 days in 2024) impacts the total service duration calculation.

claim_ui_checks.claim: The system calculates days worked with a potential extra day, causing slight variations in gratuity calculation (622 vs 623 days). The platform captures 623 days instead of the expected 622 days when computing length of service.

checks.name: semantic_days_calculation_discrepancy
checks.claim_text: The system calculates days worked with a potential extra day, causing slight variations in gratuity calculation (622 vs 623 days). The platform captures 623 days instead of the expected 622 days when computing length of service.

claim_ui_checks.claim: System calculates leave salary based on predefined policy configuration, which may not align with user expectations about calendar days and prorated calculations. The daily wage is divided according to policy settings (potentially 30 vs 31 days), causing potential salary amount mismatches.

checks.name: semantic_daily_wage_calculation_policy
checks.claim_text: System calculates leave salary based on predefined policy configuration, which may not align with user expectations about calendar days and prorated calculations. The daily wage is divided according to policy settings (potentially 30 vs 31 days), causing potential salary amount mismatches.

claim_ui_checks.claim: The daily wage calculator's 'working days' setting causes monthly fluctuations in leave salary accrual calculations. The daily wage rate changes based on the number of working days in each month, leading to inconsistent cumulative totals.

checks.name: semantic_working_days_calculation_variance
checks.claim_text: The daily wage calculator's 'working days' setting causes monthly fluctuations in leave salary accrual calculations. The daily wage rate changes based on the number of working days in each month, leading to inconsistent cumulative totals.

claim_ui_checks.claim: The system uses different divisors for leave salary (30 days) and salary proration (30.42 days), causing calculation mismatches. This leads to inconsistent daily wage calculations between leave salary and salary proration scenarios.

checks.name: semantic_daily_wage_divisor_configuration
checks.claim_text: The system uses different divisors for leave salary (30 days) and salary proration (30.42 days), causing calculation mismatches. This leads to inconsistent daily wage calculations between leave salary and salary proration scenarios.

claim_ui_checks.claim: User initially misunderstood how working days are calculated based on work week configuration. The system was actually calculating correctly, but the user did not initially understand that their specific work week (NVK Operations) had all 7 days configured as working days.

checks.name: semantic_working_days_calculation_misunderstanding
checks.claim_text: User initially misunderstood how working days are calculated based on work week configuration. The system was actually calculating correctly, but the user did not initially understand that their specific work week (NVK Operations) had all 7 days configured as working days.

claim_ui_checks.claim: The system fails to correctly prorate salaries when an employee's departure date is in the future relative to payroll processing date. When an employee is offboarded (e.g., Nov 28th) and payroll is processed earlier (e.g., Nov 27th), the system displays the full monthly salary instead of a prorated amount.

checks.name: semantic_salary_proration_calculation_logic
checks.claim_text: The system fails to correctly prorate salaries when an employee's departure date is in the future relative to payroll processing date. When an employee is offboarded (e.g., Nov 28th) and payroll is processed earlier (e.g., Nov 27th), the system displays the full monthly salary instead of a prorated amount.

claim_ui_checks.claim: When an unpaid leave request is approved and transaction submitted, then the daily wage calculation is changed and the transaction deleted to recalculate, the system creates duplicate deductions—one with the old calculation and one with the new. Deleting the leave request does not remove associated payroll deductions.

checks.name: semantic_unpaid_leave_deduction_sync
checks.claim_text: When an unpaid leave request is approved and transaction submitted, then the daily wage calculation is changed and the transaction deleted to recalculate, the system creates duplicate deductions—one with the old calculation and one with the new. Deleting the leave request does not remove associated payroll deductions.

claim_ui_checks.claim: When public holidays are added after a leave request is created, there is a timing mismatch between Time Off and Payroll modules causing incorrect daily wage calculations. The system cannot recalculate deductions retroactively, leading to inconsistent salary deduction amounts.

checks.name: semantic_public_holiday_calculation_mismatch
checks.claim_text: When public holidays are added after a leave request is created, there is a timing mismatch between Time Off and Payroll modules causing incorrect daily wage calculations. The system cannot recalculate deductions retroactively, leading to inconsistent salary deduction amounts.

claim_ui_checks.claim: The system calculates unpaid leave deductions using a custom daily wage divisor (30.42 days) instead of calendar days, which can produce deduction amounts that differ from user expectations

checks.name: semantic_unpaid_leave_calculation_complexity
checks.claim_text: The system calculates unpaid leave deductions using a custom daily wage divisor (30.42 days) instead of calendar days, which can produce deduction amounts that differ from user expectations

claim_ui_checks.claim: The system displays incorrect number of days (31 instead of 29) in remarks for February unpaid leave deduction, despite accurate backend calculation. The actual deduction calculation remains mathematically correct.

checks.name: semantic_remark_display_mismatch
checks.claim_text: The system displays incorrect number of days (31 instead of 29) in remarks for February unpaid leave deduction, despite accurate backend calculation. The actual deduction calculation remains mathematically correct.

claim_ui_checks.claim: Global daily rate configuration overrides policy-specific unpaid leave calculation methods. The system calculates deductions using a global daily rate instead of the configured policy-level method (Basic Salary / Working Days), potentially leading to incorrect salary deductions.

checks.name: semantic_unpaid_leave_calculation_override
checks.claim_text: Global daily rate configuration overrides policy-specific unpaid leave calculation methods. The system calculates deductions using a global daily rate instead of the configured policy-level method (Basic Salary / Working Days), potentially leading to incorrect salary deductions.

claim_ui_checks.claim: The system shows the daily rate from the payroll processing month (May) instead of the leave occurrence month (April), causing user confusion. The actual deduction amount is calculated correctly, but the displayed daily rate does not match the month of leave.

checks.name: semantic_daily_rate_display_mismatch
checks.claim_text: The system shows the daily rate from the payroll processing month (May) instead of the leave occurrence month (April), causing user confusion. The actual deduction amount is calculated correctly, but the displayed daily rate does not match the month of leave.

claim_ui_checks.claim: Salary is based on a standard 26 working days per month (365 annual days - 52 weekly offs = 313 working days / 12 months = 26.08 days)

checks.name: semantic_working_days_calculation
checks.claim_text: Salary is based on a standard 26 working days per month (365 annual days - 52 weekly offs = 313 working days / 12 months = 26.08 days)

claim_ui_checks.claim: Payroll settings for daily wage calculator automatically override leave policy formulas for unpaid leave calculations.

checks.name: semantic_daily_wage_formula_precedence
checks.claim_text: Payroll settings for daily wage calculator automatically override leave policy formulas for unpaid leave calculations.

claim_ui_checks.claim: Unpaid leave deductions are dependent on the timing of salary configuration creation relative to leave request submission.

checks.name: semantic_salary_configuration_timing
checks.claim_text: Unpaid leave deductions are dependent on the timing of salary configuration creation relative to leave request submission.

claim_ui_checks.claim: System defaults to 365 days per year, failing to recognize 366 days in leap years during service period calculations.

checks.name: semantic_leap_year_day_counting
checks.claim_text: System defaults to 365 days per year, failing to recognize 366 days in leap years during service period calculations.

claim_ui_checks.claim: Daily wage calculations (basic + allowances / 30) consistently produce amounts slightly lower than expected due to decimal handling.

checks.name: semantic_pro_rated_calculation_precision
checks.claim_text: Daily wage calculations (basic + allowances / 30) consistently produce amounts slightly lower than expected due to decimal handling.

claim_ui_checks.claim: Monthly accrual policy prevents automatic inclusion of leave days for incomplete months during employee departure

checks.name: semantic_leave_accrual_monthly_policy
checks.claim_text: Monthly accrual policy prevents automatic inclusion of leave days for incomplete months during employee departure

claim_ui_checks.claim: Service duration is calculated by dividing total days by 365, which may not precisely account for leap years or partial years

checks.name: semantic_service_duration_calculation
checks.claim_text: Service duration is calculated by dividing total days by 365, which may not precisely account for leap years or partial years

claim_ui_checks.claim: Daily wage is calculated using a fixed divisor of 30 days (Basic/30), which cannot be modified or configured to alternative formulas

checks.name: semantic_daily_wage_fixed_divisor
checks.claim_text: Daily wage is calculated using a fixed divisor of 30 days (Basic/30), which cannot be modified or configured to alternative formulas

claim_ui_checks.claim: The platform's leave salary calculation uses a fixed divisor from policy configuration, which cannot be easily overridden for specific scenarios.

checks.name: semantic_calculation_configuration_constraint
checks.claim_text: The platform's leave salary calculation uses a fixed divisor from policy configuration, which cannot be easily overridden for specific scenarios.

claim_ui_checks.claim: Leave encashment calculations can be set to either 'working days' or 'custom days', which significantly impacts accrual reporting

checks.name: semantic_leave_encashment_calculation_method
checks.claim_text: Leave encashment calculations can be set to either 'working days' or 'custom days', which significantly impacts accrual reporting

claim_ui_checks.claim: The system calculates leave salary and salary proration using separate daily wage configurations that cannot be automatically synchronized.

checks.name: semantic_independent_daily_wage_configs
checks.claim_text: The system calculates leave salary and salary proration using separate daily wage configurations that cannot be automatically synchronized.

claim_ui_checks.claim: Salary proration calculates based on the specific work week configuration, which can result in full month calculation if all 7 days are marked as working days

checks.name: semantic_work_week_proration_logic
checks.claim_text: Salary proration calculates based on the specific work week configuration, which can result in full month calculation if all 7 days are marked as working days

claim_ui_checks.claim: Salary proration is only accurate when departure dates are in the past, creating inconsistent calculations for future-dated departures

checks.name: semantic_proration_date_sensitivity
checks.claim_text: Salary proration is only accurate when departure dates are in the past, creating inconsistent calculations for future-dated departures

claim_ui_checks.claim: When leave transactions are modified or deleted, the payroll deduction module does not automatically reconcile or remove associated deductions.

checks.name: semantic_leave_payroll_sync_limitation
checks.claim_text: When leave transactions are modified or deleted, the payroll deduction module does not automatically reconcile or remove associated deductions.

claim_ui_checks.claim: Daily wage is calculated as: (basic salary + allowance) / working days, where working days exclude weekends and public holidays specific to the employee's country of residence.

checks.name: semantic_daily_wage_calculation_constraint
checks.claim_text: Daily wage is calculated as: (basic salary + allowance) / working days, where working days exclude weekends and public holidays specific to the employee's country of residence.

claim_ui_checks.claim: Daily wage calculations are based on calendar days, with specific handling required for months with varying days (especially February in leap years).

checks.name: semantic_calendar_days_calculation
checks.claim_text: Daily wage calculations are based on calendar days, with specific handling required for months with varying days (especially February in leap years).

claim_ui_checks.claim: The platform has a global configuration that supersedes individual policy-level settings for unpaid leave calculations.

checks.name: semantic_global_configuration_precedence
checks.claim_text: The platform has a global configuration that supersedes individual policy-level settings for unpaid leave calculations.

claim_ui_checks.claim: Daily rate calculated as Basic + Allowances / Working Days, excluding public holidays

checks.name: semantic_daily_rate_calculation_logic
checks.claim_text: Daily rate calculated as Basic + Allowances / Working Days, excluding public holidays

claim_ui_checks.claim: Automated salary calculation based on actual working days

checks.name: semantic_salary_proration_automation
checks.claim_text: Automated salary calculation based on actual working days

navigation_validation_report.disclaimer: Navigation paths are sourced from Zendesk documentation and serve as GUIDANCE ONLY. The actual UI may differ as menus change over time. Failed paths indicate potential documentation updates needed, NOT system errors. Conceptual process flows (business workflows) are identified using procedures context and are NOT treated as clickable menu paths.
